text: Patient: I don’t know. Doctor: Why do you make me work so hard? Patient: I don’t know. Doctor: My brain is on overdrive. Nice to see you both. I’m like racking my brain to see how to move forward and I’m just bummed out that you’re still in pain. Is this right? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Same place? Patient: Legs, mostly the legs, a little bit in the back, but I wanted to address the fatigue. That’s really… Doctor: Yeah, you just feel wiped out? Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Is that still a reaction from radiation six months ago? Doctor: No. Family Member: No, He shouldn’t have any effects from the radiation at this point? Doctor: No, I mean the only sort of culprit is untreated prostate cancer. You know if I had to sort of go back and we go a round of a bunch of pills

text: Family Member: Maybe put that down so you can focus some again on the radium study. Doctor: So I, I was going to talk to you about a radioactive thing we have that’s very specifically targeted the prostate cancer cells. Uh, I keep telling folks about it, and then it keeps taking too long, and we haven’t opened the trial yet. I thought we were going to open it in August. It’s now December. Family Member: What’s the name of it? Patient: Radium. Doctor: Well, no, the radium’s a different thing. So the radium, uh, this is called, this is just, it’s P-S-M-A, targeted, uh. Family Member: But it hasn’t gotten here yet? They looking at it in kind of-? Doctor: So, they’ve, they’ve tested it in Europe in a, in a weird way. So in Europe, the doctors there are allowed to, if they think something could work, they’re allowed to just give it to people. They don’t need FDA kind of approval. Doctor: They don’t need, uh, even data showing that it proves survival. It’s sort of, if, if the doctor feels it could be beneficial, they’re allowed to use it. So they’re not allowed to sell it. They not allowed to make money. So what they’ve been doing is based on using the same material to image prostate cancer. So we give this material with a little bit of radiation on it and it looks really good. We could see spots that we maybe didn’t see before. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: The idea was, well, if we can swap out the little bit of radiation and put a lot of radiation, maybe we could treat cancer. So they’ve been treating people kind of on an individual basis. Somebody calls up, shows up, you give it to them. They haven’t said, let’s take a hundred guys with this, you know, kind of like a trial. So they’ve been reporting look how good Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: So in the U.S., we kind of have to go down more organized, you know, step-wise fashion. Family Member: Um hum.

text: Patient: Yeah. Doctor: For this, I’ve got a, I think for this, the trial, they were able to use the experience with Germany to say you probably could start about here. You don’t have to start way down here. And I don’t think it’s the same exactly like a regular drug phase one. So I think they’re kind of already in a in a sort of Goldilocks spot. Patient: Okay. Okay. Doctor: So that’s the only difference between you know in Germany everybody gets, they individualize it based on what they looked at is how much of the scan is your cancer taking off. They try, they, they describe what they said that if you took up that much material, you need to get this much. Patient: Yes. Doctor: So they give, they dose it based on how much of an exposure. Patient: Um hum. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So I think, I think, again, what’s the best way to go? I mean the groups in Germany have way more experience doing this. Family Member: Um hum. Um hum. Doctor: Uh but you know it’s more complicated because you’ve got to go to Germany and all that, all those, there’s, there’s a layer to it. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Although you know saying that, you still would have to go away from home.

text: Patient: That’s it. Doctor: No other medicines for pain, anything else for the allergies – Patient: No. Doctor: Or vitamins? Patient: No. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Well, the catheter was blocked. Doctor: Okay. Patient: So I went again back to the emergency hospital and they made a mistake; they pulled it out. I still couldn’t pee. Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
